text: Special Report number 238. 14 minutes 30 seconds coming in 3, 2, 1. NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, presents a special report on the Gamma-ray Observatory. For many years, astronomers learned about the universe by looking at it in the narrow part of the electromagnetic spectrum called visible light. Later, they discovered that stars send out kinds of energy that we cannot see, such as infrared and ultraviolet radiation, radio waves, x-rays, and gamma rays. Each part of the spectrum has its own contributions to make to our understanding of the universe. The Gamma Ray Observatory, scheduled to be launched by the Space Shuttle in 1988, will be a powerful tool for understanding some of the most fascinating objects in space, Pulsars, quasars, active galaxies, and black holes. Whenever one of these violent events takes place in the universe, a supernova explosion or a black hole or a pulsar, lots of very, very energetic processes take place. Dr. Donald Niffen is project scientist for the Gamma Ray Observatory at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. Because gamma rays are such high energy, that means in these processes, in these interactions which occur, then a lot of energy is available to go into things like gamma rays. Now the way that we learn about any object viewing it through astronomy is of course we don't have direct access where we can make so-called in situ measurements. You have to deduce what's going on in the vicinity of the place where the gamma rays are being produced by the things that you can see. Gamma rays, like any other photon, travel directly from the source to us so we know or can make a good guess as to what object they're coming from. But what we want to learn about by observing the gamma rays is what mechanism is occurring. This then tells us about the physics that's going on in the source and hence what sort of types of violet reactions are taking place. From this then we can learn about things like the evolution of our universe. We can learn about the actual details of the supernova process where very heavy elements are believed to be formed. The observatory has four detectors on it that are designed to look for different aspects of gamma-ray astronomy, one that looks at gamma-ray bursts, and one that looks primarily for high-energy gamma rays. For the details, back to Dr. Niffen. What we mean by gamma ray bursts here is that there have been phenomena observed for the last 10 years or so which are observed to be very short, intense bursts of gamma rays. These are fairly low-energy gamma rays, so this instrument is optimized to look at low energies. The idea here is to try to find out what the origin of these bursts is. PHILIP GREENEY FISHERMANISTERS, IT'S STILL A PUZZLE IN SPITE OF THE FACT THAT WE HAVE BEEN ABLE TO OBSERVE THEM NOW FOR SEVERAL YEARS. WHAT WE NEED TO DO IS FIND OUT WHERE THESE SOURCES ARE. WE DON'T HAVE A GOOD IDEA OF WHERE THEY ARE. WE'VE GOT TO PINPOINT THEIR LOCATIONS BETTER SO THAT WE CAN LOOK AT THEM WITH OTHER TYPES OF TELESCOPE, GROUND-BASED OBSERVATORIES, THE SPACE TELESCOPE, AND FIND OUT THINGS ABOUT THE OTHER REGIONS OF THE ELECTROMAGNETIC SPECTRUM AND PUT ALL OF THESE PIECES OF THE puzzle together to understand where these sources are and what is causing these short, intense bursts. One number that we like to quote to show the significance of these bursts is that one was observed to come from what we believe to be outside our galaxy. And if we've actually pinpointed that source properly, then as much energy was received from that one source in these gamma rays in one tenth of a second as that emitted by our sun in a thousand years in all forms of energy that's emitted. So we're talking really about very, very intense sources. That's one instrument that's on the Gamma-ray Observatory. A second instrument is designed to make very detailed measurements of the energy of each individual gamma ray that is detected. We can look for abundances of these gamma rays at given energies, these so-called gamma-ray lines, which are then signatures of the process that's occurring to produce them. This instrument would look for things like supernovae, lines produced in supernovae, and other such phenomena. The phenomena such as the annihilation of matter and antimatter, which also gives unique signatures. Most of our universe is made of matter. On the other hand, we know that for every particle of matter, theoretically there is a particle of antimatter. When a particle of matter comes into contact with a particle of antimatter, they tend to annihilate or destroy each other. Again, Dr. Niffin explains. Using the standard Einstein formula of energy is equal to mc-squared, the matter is converted into energy. A lot of this energy often ends up in the form of gamma rays. Usually when this happens, the gamma rays are produced at a very precise energy. and you can observe these gamma rays of these energies, then you know that that sort of annihilation takes place. Well, we do know that some antimatter does exist in our galaxy. We know, for instance, that we do have electrons, but we also have positrons, the antiparticle of the electron. They're produced in certain types of processes that we know about. They're produced even in stars that are made up of matter rather than antimatter directly. When you get a lot of these anti-electrons, antimatter electrons, the positrons, and they exist in the same region with a lot of electrons, then they can combine, they annihilate, and a lot of energy is released. And this is released at a very specific gamma-ray energy. This has been observed from the direction of the center of our galaxy. But a lot more needs to be studied to understand what sort of conditions must exist in the source region for these to occur and are they being emitted from the rest of our galaxy at some lower level that we just haven't yet been able to detect. The more sensitive detectors of the Gamma-ray Observatory will be able to see them and to map out their intensity throughout our galaxy. In fact, it might even be possible to see them coming from some very active galaxies outside of our own. A third instrument on the Gamma Ray observatory is a Compton Telescope. It's so named, a Compton Telescope, because the basic mechanism for detecting them depends upon a physical interaction called the Compton scatter. The photon comes into the detector and it scatters in the material into the detector and through this process, actually through two such interactions, the gamma ray presence is detected and you can learn things about its energy and the direction from which it came by studying the details of the interaction within the detector. This one covers the intermediate ranges. It can do some measurements of gamma-ray lines, which are more appropriate to the lower energy level. It can do some measurements of higher energy gamma rays, which start to get one into the higher energy realm of gamma rays, which is a whole different set of processes involving the nuclear interactions of very, very energetic particles such as cosmic rays. And then the highest energy instrument is a spark chamber instrument which detects gamma rays by a process called pair production. And here it's just the inverse of the process I was describing to you before. Here, now we take the energy which is contained in the gamma ray and convert it into matter. an electron and its antiparticle, a positron. We cannot easily detect the gamma-ray directly, but we can detect this electron and positron. And its interaction process has a very unique signature. We take a digitized snapshot of this process in the spark chamber. We can tell from this that a gamma-ray indeed entered into our instrument and by studying the details of the interaction we can again determine from where the gamma ray came and how much energy it had. Here we're studying the very highest energy processes. This instrument also has the best angular resolution, so we can really pinpoint the sources from which these gamma rays came and use the full capability of astronomy to go look at these sources at all wavelengths. And only now, for the first time then, will we be able to study these sources at the broadest range of wavelengths possible and fully understand everything that's going on within the sources. I don't mean to imply that we're going to answer all the questions of astrophysics, but we think we're going to make giant steps forward when we can open up the complete electromagnetic spectrum to observation. Dr. David Thompson, also from Goddard Space Flight Center, gave us an example of some of the kinds of contributions the Gamma Ray Observatory can make. The Gamma Ray Observatory will help scientists understand pulsars. These objects in space were first discovered by radio astronomers. It is now thought that a pulsar is a rapidly rotating neutron star, a remnant of a star that once lived. Dr. David Thompson said that when a star dies in a supernova explosion, it leaves behind a tiny core of extremely dense material. The example we always like to use is if you had a sugar cube made out of neutron star material, it would weigh about 300 million tons on the surface of the Earth, a sugar cube. So this is what a neutron star is like. These neutron stars are spinning, and as they spin, they put out pulses of radio emission, and some of these are now known to really put out pulses of gamma ray emission. Those that we've studied indicate that, even though there are lots more radio waves seen from these, most of the energy that we see coming out of a pulsar is actually in the form of gamma rays. And that means that by studying the gamma rays we learn something about what it's like around a neutron star, A place that's so exotic and foreign that we can't even picture it on Earth. The forces that make the universe change are those that are reflected in the high-energy processes like pulsars and quasars. And by learning about the gamma rays that come from these, we learn about the mechanisms that make these exotic objects work. Quasars have always been considered exotic because they appear to be moving away from us at a large fraction of the speed of light, which may indicate that they're somewhere in the very distant parts of the universe. And yet the fact that we can see them indicates that they are radiating tremendous amounts of energy and may indeed be powered by black holes. Well, if you want to understand what's going on somewhere down near a black hole... You can't see into a black hole, of course. That's one of the main principles of that. It swallows up everything that comes to its surface. But if you want to see what's going on near a black hole you have to get out something that involves a large amount of energy and that's a gamma ray. There are a number of processes by which the matter falling into a black hole or spiraling around a black hole can radiate gamma rays. And we think that in the case of the quasars that we're seeing we may indeed be seeing down into the central what some scientists called the infernal machine that's down in the middle of a quasar. The Gamma-ray Observatory will also be able to detect gamma rays from solar flares and help us to learn what it is about our sun that can produce such violent outbursts of energy. There are a number of ways in which gamma rays can help us learn about the early universe. Again, Dr. David Thompson. There are gamma rays coming from all parts of the sky, and studies of this indicate that they're probably coming almost uniformly, and that there is a background that comes almost uniformly from all parts of the sky. means it's probably coming from outside our own galaxy, and may indeed be coming from far back in not only space but in time, near the beginning of the Universe. Dr. Niffen mentioned the question of the existence of matter and antimatter in the Universe in equal proportions. Some theoreticians would believe that there are indeed antigalaxies, or anticlusters of galaxies, in which everything is made of antimatter, And, theories have been developed based on this concept, in which the edges at the universe between clusters of galaxies, which are matter, and clusters of galaxies, which are antimatter, at the edges you have this process of annihilation in which matter and antimatter meet and annihilate. You probably remember this is what powered the Starship Enterprise in the old Star Trek series. And, it indeed is a source of energy. It comes out in the form of gamma rays. and we can look, therefore, back in time at these gamma rays that we're seeing. The Gamma Ray Observatory will help scientists answer questions on the largest possible scale. What makes the universe go? What makes solar flares on the sun? What drives quasars and pulsars? Because gamma rays are so powerful, astronomers firmly believe the observatory may detect things deep in the universe which we never knew existed. NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, has presented a special report on the GammaRay Observatory.
